attributes.title: Protocol for a scoping review of national policies for healthy ageing in Mainland China from 2016 to 2020
attributes.description:
Background: There is strong political willingness to address healthy ageing in China with the first national policy with a focus on healthy ageing independently released by the Chinese Central Government in 2017. However, there remains limited literature to understand all national polices related to healthy ageing in China over the last five-year planning cycle, from 2016 to 2020. This scoping review will systematically map national policies for healthy ageing in mainland China from 2016 to 2020.

Methods: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis: Extension for Scoping Review (PRISMA-ScR) will be used to guide the proposed study. A complete search for healthy ageing-related policy documents satisfying the eligibility criteria will be performed in all departments affiliated to the State Council of China and relevant websites of English and Chinese grey literature. Essential information from all eligible policy documents will be extracted and mapped to a pre-defined two-dimensional framework generated from the World health Organization’s health system building blocks and Rothwell and Zegveld’s innovation policy instrument.

Discussions: It is anticipated that the results of this study will provide an in-depth overview of national policies of healthy ageing issued between 2016 and 2020 in Mainland China, and aid identification of strengths and gaps in healthy ageing policy response. Findings may facilitate policy makers to optimize the policy formulation related to healthy ageing and realign the national health system to better support the needs of the older population. This study also describes the general paradigm of policy process and essential conceptions used to conduct a systematic study on national policies in China, which might be useful to guide policy research on other topics.

q1.value: Pengpeng Ye, Yuliang Er, Leilei Duan, Anna Palagyi, Rebecca Ivers, Lisa Keay, Maoyi Tian

q2.value:
Population ageing, while one of humanity’s great successes due to both public health policies and social and economic development, also raises many challenges for society. It is projected that the proportion of the people aged 60 years or over around the world will double from 11% in 2000 to 22% by 2050, with an estimated total of 2.1 billion people. This dramatic growth in the older population will not only occur in high-income countries, but also in many low- and middle-income countries. In China, the acceleration of population ageing has surpassed that of many higher-income countries. Between 2010 and 2040, the proportion of adults aged 60 years and over in China is expected to more than double, from 12.4% to 28%. This looming demographic shift in China will present considerable social and economic challenges. 

In response to this emerging burden, the 69th World Health Assembly in 2016 adopted the Global Strategy and Action Plan on Ageing and Health. Five strategic objectives with 15 priority areas for action were identified to align with the vision of healthy ageing for all. In China, healthy ageing has subsequently become a key priority in Chinese central government’s agenda for health and development. However, despite strong political willingness to address healthy ageing in China, there remains limited literature to understand all national polices related to healthy ageing in China over the last five year planning cycle, from 2016 to 2020.

Therefore, this scoping review will systematically map national policies for healthy ageing in Mainland China from 2016 to 2020. Specifically, it will determine the nature, extent and range of those national healthy ageing-related policies and assess how they align the health system to the needs of the older population to fulfil the vision of healthy ageing proposed by the World Health Assembly.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value:
In China, the State Council is the highest executive body of state power and the highest organ of the state administration. It directly supervises the subordinate people's governments in the provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities, and special administrative regions. The State Council is responsible for implementing the principles and policies of the Communist Party of China, as well as regulations and laws adopted by the NPC, and executes the power of administrative legislation, proposals submission, and administrative leadership, as well as the power of management in the field of internal politics, diplomacy, national defence, finance, economy, culture, education, and other internal affairs. The structure of the State Council has undergone eight adjustments since 1982, with the latest structure launched in 2018 comprising of 26 constituent departments. National policies of healthy aging are formulated and promulgated by the State Council and its affiliated departments 

Therefore, the primary information sources will include (1) Chinese State Council website; and (2) the websites of all departments affiliated to the State Council. The search will be supplemented by a grey literature search in both English and Chinese. English grey literature includes OpenGrey, Grey Literature Report, GreyNet International 2019, websites of international organizations including United Nations (UN), World Bank (WB), Asian Development Bank (ADB) and World Health Organization (WHO). Chinese grey literature will be searched from the websites of National Institute for Global Strategy, Center for Public Policy Research, China Policy Research Network, and China Policy Network, E-China Government, Data People, and websites of Chinese electronic policy databases including Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), Wanfang Data, and Big data of Policy.

question.value:
There is no uniform search function in the websites of all departments affiliated to the State Council and the websites of English and Chinese grey literature. Search strategies for these policy sources will be developed separately and further refined through team discussion. A search will be performed within individual websites of departments affiliated to the State Council if the following criteria are met: (1) there is an explicit policy classification from search results; or (2) a policy section with an independent search function provided, or (3) a policy database with an independent search function provided, and (4) the search function could be executed correctly. If these criteria cannot be met, a search will be performed within a web search engine (Baidu and Google) and restricted in the policy section or policy database of websites. 

Keywords used to identify polices targeting on older people in Chinese are Lao Nian (older people), Lao Ling (older people), Yang Lao (older people), Shi Lao (older people), Gao Ling (older people), and Lao Ren (older people), and in English are old, elder, aged, and ageing. A librarian will be contacted via email for their suggestions on all search strategies. The search terms in each strategy will be modified if there is a need. The search process will be iteratively executed if a new source is provided or emerging.

q12.value: Websites of all departments affiliated to the State Council and the websites of English and Chinese grey literature will be systematically searched to identify healthy ageing policy documents published between January 1, 2016 and December 31, 2020, which is the ‘Thirteenth Five-Year Plan’ cycle in China. The ‘Five-Year Plan’ is a terminology developed by the former Soviet Union to plan the economic growth over limited periods and was introduced to China from 1953. It usually takes Chinese central government two years to develop the ‘Five-Year Plan’ from the first draft to the final document reviewed by the National People's Congress (NPC). The ‘Five-Year Plan’ sets specific goals and provides directions for the national social-economic development in China.

question.value: The data extraction will be performed in three phases. In phase 1, one reviewer (PY) will perform the search in all information sources. In phase 2, one reviewer (PY) will screen the title of all identified policies and remove all duplicates. In phase 3, the full text of potential eligible policies will be independently reviewed by two reviewers (PY and YE). Review of the first 10 polices will be completed by both reviewers and used as a training session to ensure a minimum of 95% inter-reviewer agreement. Any discrepancies will be discussed to reach consensus. Extracted data will include: i) essential information of policy documents, i.e., name, department source, issue date, type, audience; and ii) essential information of policy contents, i.e., background, objective, target population, target settings, proposed strategies/measures, outcome indicators, executive departments, financial support, performance evaluation methods, and date of implementation. The listed data items could be modified as reviewers become more familiar with policy documents. A data-charting form will be jointly developed by two reviewers and further refined through team discussion.

A two-dimensional framework will be generated for data synthesis. Firstly, given the goal of assessing how policies for healthy ageing address the alignment of the health system to the needs of older population, the X-axis is coded and constructed from the third strategic objective, ‘aligning health systems to the needs of older populations’ using WHO health system framework. This objective was set in the ‘Global strategy and action plan on ageing and health’ adopted by the Sixty-ninth World Health Assembly in May 2016. Secondly, given the large and urgent demand for programs and services to support healthy ageing with insufficient supply, the Y-axis will be based on the classification of the innovation policy instrument developed by Rothwell and Zegveld. This policy instrument classifies government policies into three broad categories: supply, demand and environment policies.

q20.value: Eligible policy documents should meet all following inclusion criteria: (1) the policy document was issued between 2016 and 2020; (2) the policy document was published by the department affiliated to the State Council; (3) the eligible type and function of policy document; (4) the main content of the policy document was associated with one or more of nine domains in healthy ageing; and (5) the policy targets older people nationally. Exclusion criteria include: (1) any policy document published before 2016, or (2) the full text of the policy was not publicly available, or (3) the policy document was particularly for an issue in a specific year, region, or institution, or (4) the policy document was particularly evaluating, monitoring, and summarizing a specific work or project, or (5) the policy document was particular for the publishment of a technical standard, or (6) the policy document was purely for the publishment of statistical data.

q23.value: This scoping review will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-analysis extension for Scoping Reviews (PRSIMA-ScR) Checklist.

registration_responses.q1: Pengpeng Ye, Yuliang Er, Leilei Duan, Anna Palagyi, Rebecca Ivers, Lisa Keay, Maoyi Tian

It is projected that the proportion of the people aged 60 years or over around the world will double from 11% in 2000 to 22% by 2050, with an estimated total of 2.1 billion people. This dramatic growth in the older population will not only occur in high-income countries, but also in many low- and middle-income countries. In China, the acceleration of population ageing has surpassed that of many higher-income countries. Between 2010 and 2040, the proportion of adults aged 60 years and over in China is expected to more than double, from 12.4% to 28%. This looming demographic shift in China will present considerable social and economic challenges. 

In response to this emerging burden, the 69th World Health Assembly in 2016 adopted the Global Strategy and Action Plan on Ageing and Health. Five strategic objectives with 15 priority areas for action were identified to align with the vision of healthy ageing for all. In China, healthy ageing has subsequently become a key priority in Chinese central government’s agenda for health and development. However, despite strong political willingness to address healthy ageing in China, there remains limited literature to understand all national polices related to healthy ageing in China over the last five year planning cycle, from 2016 to 2020.

Specifically, it will determine the nature, extent and range of those national healthy ageing-related policies and assess how they align the health system to the needs of the older population to fulfil the vision of healthy ageing proposed by the World Health Assembly.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Silhouette Database
attributes.description: PILOT STUDY in our endeavour to create a Cross-Cultural Bicoloured Affective Silhouette & Shape (BASS) Database.

summary.value:
Pre-Study 1: Vienna University

1. Aim
This will be the first pre-study we run in our endeavour to create a Bicolour Affective Silhouette & Shape (BASS) database. Valence and arousal for 620 silhouette pictures will be rated by students from the University of Vienna.

Eventually we plan to obtain ratings across different culture/language groups like German/Austrian, English/American, Chinese, and/or Korean, in order to provide a normed, cross-culturally valid set of silhouette stimuli. In this pre-study, however, participants will be students from the University of Vienna. Before running the main experiment, the two main purposes of this pre-study are (a) to eleminate images that are unclear (i.e., not clearly recognizable; based on clarity ratings as well as on the standard deviations of other – valence and arousal – ratings) and (b) to test whether giving ratings for valence and arousal separately or together influences the respective ratings.

2. Methods 
2.1 Material
Most silhouettes were acquired through internet search using Google Images (images.google.com) under the creative commons license, searching either directly for silhouettes or pictures that we edited into black-white-silhouettes using GIMP. 

We restricted our image search to images labelled “available for reuse with modification”.
The sources of the silhouettes are most notably Pixabay (pixabay.com; N = 477), CleanPNG (cleanpng.com; N = 34), and svgsilh (svgsilh.com; N = 32). Twenty silhouettes were created for this project by a graphic designer/illustrator. We collected a wide range of pictures, depicting persons, animals, objects, and scenes, which we indicate in a category column in the database for easier stimulus selection. Special focus was put on collecting positive, negative and neutral pictures of either low, medium, or high arousal. Every picture was scaled and/or cropped to a size of 300 x 300 pixels. 

Silhouette Colour Manipulation: We will present the silhouettes in two different versions to the participants. We will provide information on the white-to-black ratio (pixel count of white vs. black pixels) in the database, so that researchers can utilize this control measure in their studies when using material from the database. In addition, we are curious as to how inverted (white on black background) and non-inverted (black on white background) ratings would differ from each other – if at all. Importantly, we hope that the ratings will remain generally similar at least comparatively among the images, i.e. we expect a correlation between black-on-white and white-on-black images. This manipulation would provide an additional measure for the impact of brightness on emotion ratings.  

2.2 Participants
Avoiding Valence-Arousal Contamination: 
Group 1, 4: Rates stimuli on the valence dimension 
Group 2, 5: Rates stimuli on the arousal dimension 
Group 3, 6: Rates stimuli on the valence and the arousal dimension

Participants (students from the University of Vienna) are randomly assigned to one of the six resulting conditions permuting rating mode and colour mode (black-on-white or white-on-black). We stop data collection for the pilot when we reach 100 participants or after March 18, 2020 (data collection will start earliest February 24, 2020).

2.3 Procedure / Data collection
General Procedure: After the informed consent and demographical data, we will adequately explain the terms valance and/or arousal to the participants, depending on which rating condition the participant is assigned to. After the instruction, the experiment starts. Participants see a silhouette stimulus (300 x 300 px) on a grey background (hex colour #808080) for 2 s. After this time elapsed, the picture disappears and is replaced with the rating scales: the lower rating scale is always on clarity (9 pt likert scale from very unclear to very clear; German: Eindeutigkeit; labels absolut unklar, recht unklar, weiß nicht, recht klar, absolut klar). Above appears either a valence rating scale (9 pt likert scale from very negative to very positive; German: Valenz; labels sehr negativ, recht negativ, neutral, recht positiv, sehr positiv), or an arousal scale (9 pt likert scale from very low to very high; German: Arousal; labels sehr niedrig, recht niedrig, weder hoch noch niedrig, recht hoch, sehr hoch), or both scales. Participants can enter their ratings via clicks on the scales and submit their rating by pressing a button that appears below the scales, or they can skip the rating. After confirming their choice, the next picture appears on screen, and so on. A total of 150 pictures is presented to each participant. We incorporate two attention checks:

Attention Check 1: After all 155 rating trials, a black-and-white picture is shown after which participants have to indicate, what was depicted on it (this will be the same item for all participants) out of a list of answers. Participants who do not answer this question correctly will have failed Attention Check 1.

Attention Check 2/Intrarater Reliability: Following Attention Check 1, for Groups 1, 4 and 3, 6 (Valence rating only, and Valence & Arousal rating), five of the most negatively and five of the most positively rated pictures are repeated (constituting the last 10 trials of the experiment). For Groups 2, 5 (Arousal rating only), five of the least arousing and five of the most arousing pictures are repeated. For those stimuli pairs, both instances of the rating will be tested for correlation (Spearman, see Statistical Analysis). 

2.4 Exclusions
For each silhouette, participants have the option to skip the rating. Data from participants who skip the rating for more than 50% of the items will be discarded. Moreover, data from participants who fail Attention Check 1 will be discarded. Note: Attention Check 2 will not yet be used for exclusions in this first pilot study.

3 Statistical Analysis 
The main dependent variables are the average ratings given for each picture, for valence, and for arousal, in the two conditions (Separate or Together).

3.1 Avoiding Valence-Arousal Contamination: 
As a preliminary check, we will conduct two analyses of variance (ANOVAs) to see whether presenting two rating scales separately has an absolute effect on either of the measures (i.e., positive or negative shift in average ratings for valence or for arousal). We report Bayes factors based on matched models.

For black-on-white Silhouettes: We will check if ratings from Group 3 differ significantly from those of Groups 1 and 2. This will be done by running an ANOVA with Dimension (Valence vs. Arousal) × Condition (Together vs. Separate) as within-picture factors. 

For white-on-black Silhouettes: We will check if ratings from Group 6 differ significantly from those of Groups 4 and 5. This will be done by running an ANOVA with Dimension (Valence vs. Arousal) × Condition (Together vs. Separate) as within-picture factors. 

More importantly, we will check whether the ratings of one measure are directly influenced by the ratings for the other measure. For example, we might expect that, after giving a high arousal rating value, participants would tend to give a higher value (and hence more positive value) for valence, and vice versa, e.g. simply because they already hold the cursor closer to these values.

For this, we will perform four correlation tests (including corresponding Bayes factors). First, taking the average rating values per picture, we correlate the arousal ratings in Separate conditions with the difference between the valence Together and the valence Separate ratings. If significant correlation is found, it means that higher ratings for arousal indeed resulted in higher valence ratings when rated together, as compared to when rated separately. The second correlation is the reverse, testing the influence of valence on arousal: we correlate the valence ratings in Separate condition with the difference between the arousal Together and the arousal Separate ratings. The two additional correlations will be similar, except that the difference will be taken not between rating means, but from ratings SDs (standard deviations): We correlate the arousal rating averages in Separate condition with the difference between the valence Together rating SDs and the valence Separate rating SDs. Vice versa for the effect of valence average on arousal SDs.

3.2 Differences in black-on-white vs. white-on-black
We will check in a Silhouette Type (black-on-white vs. white-on-black) x Rating mode (Valence vs. Arousal) ANOVA, if valence and/or arousal ratings diverge significantly from each other, when comparing black silhouettes on white background (Condition 1) to their white silhouette on black background (Condition 2) counterparts. 

We will also conduct a simple correlation test between the ratings obtained in the two conditions, expecting high correlation.

3.3 Attention Check 2/Intrarater Reliability
This pre-study will set the threshold on intrarater reliability for the big-scale online rating study, which is to follow. We expect participating students to have a relatively high level of concentration and that they pay proper attention throughout the experiment. The analysis on the correlation for the attention check items (see section 2.3 Procedure / Data collection) will give us an idea on which threshold we should set for the correlation in the following online study.

registration_responses.summary:
Pre-Study 1: Vienna University

1. Aim
This will be the first pre-study we run in our endeavour to create a Bicolour Affective Silhouette & Shape (BASS) database. Valence and arousal for 620 silhouette pictures will be rated by students from the University of Vienna.

Eventually we plan to obtain ratings across different culture/language groups like German/Austrian, English/American, Chinese, and/or Korean, in order to provide a normed, cross-culturally valid set of silhouette stimuli. For white-on-black Silhouettes: We will check if ratings from Group 6 differ significantly from those of Groups 4 and 5. This will be done by running an ANOVA with Dimension (Valence vs. Arousal) × Condition (Together vs. Separate) as within-picture factors. 

More importantly, we will check whether the ratings of one measure are directly influenced by the ratings for the other measure. For example, we might expect that, after giving a high arousal rating value, participants would tend to give a higher value (and hence more positive value) for valence, and vice versa, e.g. simply because they already hold the cursor closer to these values.

For this, we will perform four correlation tests (including corresponding Bayes factors). First, taking the average rating values per picture, we correlate the arousal ratings in Separate conditions with the difference between the valence Together and the valence Separate ratings. If significant correlation is found, it means that higher ratings for arousal indeed resulted in higher valence ratings when rated together, as compared to when rated separately. The second correlation is the reverse, testing the influence of valence on arousal: we correlate the valence ratings in Separate condition with the difference between the arousal Together and the arousal Separate ratings. The two additional correlations will be similar, except that the difference will be taken not between rating means, but from ratings SDs (standard deviations): We correlate the arousal rating averages in Separate condition with the difference between the valence Together rating SDs and the valence Separate rating SDs. Vice versa for the effect of valence average on arousal SDs.

3.2 Differences in black-on-white vs. white-on-black
We will check in a Silhouette Type (black-on-white vs. white-on-black) x Rating mode (Valence vs. Arousal) ANOVA, if valence and/or arousal ratings diverge significantly from each other, when comparing black silhouettes on white background (Condition 1) to their white silhouette on black background (Condition 2) counterparts. 

We will also conduct a simple correlation test between the ratings obtained in the two conditions, expecting high correlation.

3.3 Attention Check 2/Intrarater Reliability
This pre-study will set the threshold on intrarater reliability for the big-scale online rating study, which is to follow. We expect participating students to have a relatively high level of concentration and that they pay proper attention throughout the experiment. The analysis on the correlation for the attention check items (see section 2.3 Procedure / Data collection) will give us an idea on which threshold we should set for the correlation in the following online study.

attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of Lasmiditan for acute treatment of migraine in adults: A meta-analysis
attributes.description: The present meta-analysis has been planned to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Lasmiditan for acute treatment of migraine in adults.

summary.value:
Migraine is a neurological and disabling disease with an estimated global prevalence of approximately 12%. The pathophysiology of migraine is not completely understood and hence, the management of acute migraine is complex. The results of the American Migraine Prevalence and Prevention (AMPP) study concluded that 41% of patients with episodic migraine have significant unmet needs including relatively high rates of moderate/severe headache-related disability (47%) and dissatisfaction with the current acute medication treatment regimen. Inadequate management of migraine usually leads to an increase in the frequency of migraine attack, medication overuse and synchronicity. 
 
Triptans, selective 5-HT1B/1D agonists, are the gold standard treatment for an acute attack of migraine. However, triptans are not equally effective in all patients and are contraindicated in coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, or uncontrolled hypertension. Recent understanding of the pathophysiology of migraine has shown a shift from vasodilatation to a brain disorder involving pain and other sensory processing. In this clinical scenario, alternative therapeutic options are necessary especially in those conditions where the role of triptans are limited.

Recently, 5-HT1F receptor agonists have come up as a potential alternative to triptans. Lasmiditan, a highly selective 5-HT1F receptor agonist without any vasoconstrictive property, is a novel treatment of an acute attack of migraine. Some recent clinical trials have proved the efficacy and safety of Lasmiditan for acute treatment in migraine. Presently, the number of the clinical trials exploring the efficacy of Lasmiditan is limited and hence, it is important to generate evidence regarding the magnitude of the effect and safety of Lasmiditan for framing the therapeutic guideline. So, the present meta-analysis has been planned to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Lasmiditan for acute treatment of migraine in adults.

Migraine is a neurological and disabling disease with an estimated global prevalence of approximately 12%. The pathophysiology of migraine is not completely understood and hence, the management of acute migraine is complex. The results of the American Migraine Prevalence and Prevention (AMPP) study concluded that 41% of patients with episodic migraine have significant unmet needs including relatively high rates of moderate/severe headache-related disability (47%) and dissatisfaction with the current acute medication treatment regimen. Inadequate management of migraine usually leads to an increase in the frequency of migraine attack, medication overuse and synchronicity. 
 
Triptans, selective 5-HT1B/1D agonists, are the gold standard treatment for an acute attack of migraine. However, triptans are not equally effective in all patients and are contraindicated in coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, or uncontrolled hypertension. Recent understanding of the pathophysiology of migraine has shown a shift from vasodilatation to a brain disorder involving pain and other sensory processing. In this clinical scenario, alternative therapeutic options are necessary especially in those conditions where the role of triptans are limited.

Recently, 5-HT1F receptor agonists have come up as a potential alternative to triptans. Lasmiditan, a highly selective 5-HT1F receptor agonist without any vasoconstrictive property, is a novel treatment of an acute attack of migraine. Some recent clinical trials have proved the efficacy and safety of Lasmiditan for acute treatment in migraine. Presently, the number of the clinical trials exploring the efficacy of Lasmiditan is limited and hence, it is important to generate evidence regarding the magnitude of the effect and safety of Lasmiditan for framing the therapeutic guideline. So, the present meta-analysis has been planned to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Lasmiditan for acute treatment of migraine in adults.

attributes.title: Engaging Communities for Peace in Nigeria (ECPN)

q1.value: Engaging Communities for Peace in Nigeria (ECPN)

q2.value: Chris Grady | Rebecca Wolfe | Lisa Inks | Dawop Saidu

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: ECPN is a 2-year program in the Middle Belt of Nigeria that aims to prevent violence and conflict between farmer and pastoralist communities. During this program, we proposes to run a randomized experiment to assess the impact of quick impact community projects on conflict and attitudes. The experiment's goal is to answer the question: does individual participation in ECPN's quick-impact and other community projects cause more intergroup trust?

q16.value: (response updated on January 29, 2018)   Community-level hypotheses: For communities that receive the ECPN program, which includes a combination of mediation support, projects that a committee of farmers and pastoralists jointly decide on and implement, and community fora that prevents conflict from escalating, we will find increased trust and positive affect between farmers and pastoralists than in control communities. For communities that receive the ECPN program, we will find farmers and pastoralists are more likely to cooperate and interact with the outgroup  than control. For communities that receive the ECPN program, we will find farmers and pastoralists have more positive attitudes about the outgroup than control. Communities that receive the ECPN program will have increased security compared to control communities. Communities that receive the ECPN program will resolve disputes more peacefully compared to control communities. Individual-level hypotheses: Individuals involved in the planning and implementing of projects that benefit both farmers and pastoralists will cooperate with the outgroup more than individuals who did not participate in these activities. Individuals involved in the planning and implementing of projects that benefit both farmers and pastoralists will trust each other more  and feel more positively towards the outgroup than individuals who did not participate in these activities. Individuals involved in the planning and implementing of projects that benefit both farmers and pastoralists will interact more with the outgroup than individuals who did not participate in these activities. Individuals involved in the planning and implementing of projects that benefit both farmers and pastoralists will have more positive attitudes about the outgroup  than than individuals who did not participate in these activities. Individuals involved in more ECPN activities will cooperate more, trust each other more, have more positive attitudes about the outgroup, and interact more than those who participated in fewer ECPN activities. More specifically, we will see the most change in participants who participated in the joint projects, followed by the non-participants in the treatment communities, and then the control participants who we expect to have no change.

q17.value: (response updated on January 29, 2018)     We evaluate the effects of ECPN with a combination of a RCT at the community level and pre-post test analysis of individuals without random assignment.  Initially the plan was to randomize at both the community and individual level as follows: (1) Communities are randomly selected to be "treated" with the ECPN program or remain "control" communities, and then (2) community members in treated communities are randomly selected to participate in the programs.  Among participants selected to participate in ECPN programs, some people participate "fully" in every ECPN activity and others participate "partially" in just one ECPN activity.  This yields four experimental groups: (1) full participants in treated communities, (2) partial participants in treated communities, (3) non-participants in treated communities, and (4) non-participants in control communities.   However, due to the low compliance among those randomly selected to participate, we changed our study design to (1) a community-level RCT and (2) pre-post analysis of individuals we surveyed at baseline and endline.  In Study 1, the community-level RCT, we randomly sample 50 people from 10 treated and 5 control sites, where each site contains one farmer and one pastoralist community.  These samples are aggregated at the community level and our analysis is between communities in a difference-in-differences framework.  In Study 2, the individual-level pre-post analysis, we resurvey about 100 individuals who participated in the joint project committees and were randomly assigned to do so, about 100 individuals who were assigned to participate in the joint committee but did not because they were not located at the time the committees formed, and about 100 individuals in control sites.  Henceforth we will refer to those people who participated as “participants”, those people who did not as “non-participants”, and those people in control communities as “control.”  Study 2 will contain multiple analyses comparing these groups with a difference-in-differences frameworks.

q23.value: IRB approval received after initial submission

q25.value: Initial date of approval: September 4th, 2015. Most recent renewal/amendment: July 19, 2017.

attributes.title: The Effects of Forced Versus Selective Propaganda Exposure in China

q1.value: The Effects of Forced Versus Selective Propaganda Exposure in China

q5.value: I thank Rory Truex and Andrew Guess for their helpful comments on the research design.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Despite the efforts made to understand the effectiveness of propaganda in authoritarian countries, one question overlooked is the differential propaganda effects in various conditions under which people are exposed to these propaganda messages. Scholars long have known that media effects are heterogeneous, differing by messages and individual characters. However, less attention has been paid to varying contexts. In this study, I intend to uncover propaganda effects under two conditions: forced versus selective exposure, in the case of China.

q16.value: H1: Propaganda will be less effective for those forced to view propaganda news than those given a choice of propaganda news and non-propaganda news. H2a (affective reactance): Those forced to view propaganda news will experience more affective reactance than those given a choice of propaganda news and non-propaganda news. H2b (trivialization): Those forced to view propaganda news will rate the issues discussed in the propaganda news as less important than those given a choice of propaganda news and non-propaganda news. H2c (effort justification): Those forced to view propaganda news will rate the issues discussed in the propaganda news as more understandable than those given a choice of propaganda news and non-propaganda news.

q17.value: This study joins recent work that has modified standard experimental designs to give participants some choice over media content. More specifically, as I intend to uncover separate treatment effects (propaganda message) for selectors (selective exposure) and non-selectors (forced exposure), I will adopt Gaines and Kuklinski’s design which incorporates self-selection into the experiment.

attributes.title: INTERVENTIONS TO MODIFY FEAR IN PEOPLE WITH FIBROMYALGIA
attributes.description: Fibromyalgia is a frequent form of chronic pain associated with high levels of disability and poor quality of life. Cognitive and emotional factors play a role in the management of chronic pain. Fear of pain and fear of movement are common in people with fibromyalgia.

q2.value: The aim of this systematic review will be twofold: to (1) explore which interventions reduce fear in people with fibromyalgia, and (2) assess reporting of interventions designed to decrease fear.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of randomized trials.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
We searched Cochrane Central, CINAHL, EMBASE, PsycINFO, PubMed, and Scopus from inception up to May 2020. 
Eligibility Criteria
The inclusion criteria were: 
1.	Studies: trials.
2.	Participants: people with fibromyalgia.
3.	Interventions: conservative and/or surgical interventions designed to reduce fear.
4.	Outcome: fear measured as a primary or secondary outcome.

The exclusion criteria were:
1.	Studies with animals.

Trial Selection
Potential articles will be screened by title and abstract. Then, the full-text will be screened if the  trial selection is unclear after reading the title and abstract. We will resolve any disagreements via consensus or a third reviewer, if required.
Data Extraction
The following information will be extracted from every included study: study (year and country) and participant characteristics (age, sex, and pain duration); setting; fear details; covariates in the adjustment of treatment effects; and main findings of each included trial. Any disagreements will be resolved via consensus.

q11.value: The sample is of people with fibromyalgia. We did not calculate the sample size due to this is a systematic review design.

question.value: Fear assessed as a primary or secondary outcome. The following fear constructs will be considered: fear of pain, pain-related anxiety, fear of falling, fear-avoidance beliefs, fear of movement, and kinesiophobia.

We plan to conduct meta-analyses of effect estimates for different intervention categories and fear outcomes. If meta-analyses cannot be conducted, a narrative synthesis will be carried out. We used Cochrane Risk of Bias tool 2 to assess the risk of bias and the GRADE approach to evaluate the certainty of the evidence.

registration_responses.q2: The aim of this systematic review will be twofold: to (1) explore which interventions reduce fear in people with fibromyalgia, and (2) assess reporting of interventions designed to decrease fear.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q11: The sample is of people with fibromyalgia. We did not calculate the sample size due to this is a systematic review design.

3.	Interventions: conservative and/or surgical interventions designed to reduce fear.
4.	Outcome: fear measured as a primary or secondary outcome.

The exclusion criteria were:
1.	Studies with animals.

Trial Selection

Data Extraction

Any disagreements will be resolved via consensus.

If meta-analyses cannot be conducted, a narrative synthesis will be carried out. We used Cochrane Risk of Bias tool 2 to assess the risk of bias and the GRADE approach to evaluate the certainty of the evidence.

attributes.title: Explaining Citizen Support for Democratic Norm Violation: an online survey experiment in the United States

q1.value: Explaining Citizen Support for Democratic Norm Violation: an online survey experiment in the United States

q2.value: Gábor Simonovits, Jennifer McCoy, Levente Littvay

q3.value:
New experimental research has provided mixed results in attempting to identify the conditions under which voters are willing to trade off democratic principles in exchange for some other benefit.  Graham and Svolik (2019) find that only a small group of U.S. voters are willing to punish (vote against) democratic violators, and that those with the strongest policy preferences or partisan loyalty are the least willing to punish democratic violators.  On the other hand, Carey et al (2018) found, more hopefully, that American voters across parties and independents will punish democracy-violating hypothetical candidates on some issues, even after taking into account the stronger effects of partisan identity and policy preferences in determining vote choice. 
While the experimental studies did not, for the most part, find differences among the parties on their willingness to punish democratic violators, survey research does find partisan or ideological differences in support for democracy in the U.S., with Republicans and conservatives more likely to support behavior representing democratic norm violation (Drutman, Diamond, and Goldman, 2018a; Stolle, Gidengil, and Bergeron-Boutin 2019; Wike, et al 2017, 10; Doherty, et al 2017, 3). 
This paper employs a large online survey experiment in the United States to test whether American voters are more tolerant of behavior that violates existing democratic norms when their own party is in power, versus when the opposing party is in power.  Particularly in a context of hyper-polarization such as contemporary U.S. politics, we expect that voters will prioritize keeping their co-partisans in power over protecting existing norms, and that this will be conditioned by intensity of party identity.  Second, we test whether there are differences among Democrats and Republicans in their attitudes toward democratic-norm eroding behavior.

q4.value:
Our hypotheses are thus:
H1: Citizens are more supportive of democratic norm erosion when co-partisans are in power.

H2: Higher perceptions of out-group threat and the intensity of partisan identity increase support for democratic norm erosion when co-partisans are in power..

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study employs a between-subjects design in which participants are given a scenario about the post-2020 election results and asked a series of questions about democratic norms. In one condition, Democrats control the presidency, governorship of the respondent’s state, and at least one chamber in the Congress.  In the second condition, Republicans control those offices. Thus, for each respondent we manipulate whether the in-party or the out-party is the incumbent.

q9.value: We use simple randomization through the in-built feature of Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We field our survey through Lucid, the largest US marketplace for online panels. Participants sign up to become members of panels with Providers. These Providers contract with Lucid, who directs participants to purchasers (typically market research firms, but here us, the researchers). Participants are reimbursed by the Providers, typically with money or reward points.

q13.value: We field the experiment to a sample of 3,000 subjects in the context of a multi-investigator project. Lucid charges $1/subject and sets a maximum survey length. Thus, the size of the study was determined by the resource constraints of the collaborative team.

question.value:
The single manipulated variable in the experiment is whether subjects are prompted to imagine a scenario in which the in-party or the out-party controls government. Specifically, before answering to our outcome measures subjects read one of the preambles below:

Condition 1 - Democrats in power: For the next set of  questions about the government, imagine this  scenario:  It's January 2021, and the new president, Senate and Congress and state level officials are  being inaugurated following the 2020 elections. The Democrats have made a sweep, winning the presidency, the Senate, and the governorship of your state.  In a few of the questions below, though, the Republicans have won a majority in the Congress (House of Representatives).

Condition 2 -- Republicans in power:  For the next set of  questions about the government, imagine this  scenario:  It's January 2021, and the new president, Senate and Congress and state level officials are  being inaugurated following the 2020 elections. The Republicans have made a sweep, winning the presidency, the Senate, and the governorship of your state.  In a few of the questions below, though, the Democrats have retained a majority in the Congress (House of Representatives).

Pre-treatment measures:

Pre-treatment variables

Because we are interested in the relative attitudes of our subjects towards individuals belonging to their in-party and out-party, we first elicit their partisan identification using the ANES questions to identify party supporters and party-leaners for both the Democratic and Republican parties.  We terminate true independents or smaller third parties.

We also measure subjects’ partisan identity strength using a series of 4 questions developed by Huddy, Mason and Aaroe (2015). 


How well does the term Democrat/Republican describe you? (Extremely well - Not well at all)
How important is being a Democrat/Republican to you? (Extremely important - not at all important)
When talking about Democrat/Republican, how often do you use "we" instead of "they"? (Never - All the time)
How much do you have a lot in common with other ${e://Field/respondent_party}s. (Not at all-Great deal)

We combine these responses - all measured on a 5 point scale - to come up with a continuous measure of identity strength. Given that we have found during our pilots that this variable is highly predictive of our outcome of interest we use this variable as a covariate in our statistical analysis.

Finally, we measure perceptions of out-group threat using the items below:

When you look at Democrat/Republican politicians, would you agree that their policies are so misguided they threaten the country's well-being?  [Only the out-party politician/party is displayed]
When you look at President Trump/Bernie Sanders, would you agree that his policies are so misguided they threaten the country's well-being?  [Only the out-party politician/party is displayed]
When you look at people who don't share your values, would you say the policies they advocate are so misguided they threaten the country's well-being?  

We combine responses to these three items to an additive index of threat-perception.


Outcomes

We ask a series of questions about 16 hypothetical situations. In each of these situation we ask subjects to choose between two alternative with one labeled as "norm-eroding" (see wording and response options in the document attached). From these responses we construct a measure of norm erosion using a two parameter IRT model.

For the pre-treatment variables we use simple additive indices scaled to lie between 0 and 100.

For the outcome measures we use a two-parameter IRT model to obtain an estimate of the latent preference for norm erosion.

H1: We compare our measure of support for democratic norm erosion across scenarios where co-partisans vs. the out-party is in power. We do so by estimating a simple regression predicting the outcome by an indicator for experimental group.

H2: Higher perceptions of out-group threat and the intensity of partisan identity increase support for democratic norm erosion when co-partisans are in power..

We test this hypothesis by estimating a regression predicting the outcome by an indicator for experimental group interacted with (a) our composite measure of partisan identity strength and (b) or composite measure of threat perception. We estimates these two models separately.

We will also estimate the models above separately for Republican and Democrat respondents.

q21.value: We will report 95% Confidence intervals corresponding to two-sided tests.

q22.value:
We give an attention check to terminate respondents indicative of fraudulent responses. In particular,  they responded to a “trick question” proposed by Berinsky et al (2014). Then, we ask them to respond to a simple open ended question about a movie they had watched recently. We do so in order to screen out respondents unwilling or unable to engage with the essay writing stimuli which are our experimental interventions. Finally, because our hypotheses pertain to individuals with some attachment to either the Democrat or Republican party we terminate the survey for individuals who identify as pure independents. 

Thus, our analysis sample will consist of survey takers that 

(1) Identify or lean Democrat or Republican as per our ANES type question
(2) Pass our screener questions.

q23.value: We force respondents to respond to each of our outcome measures to continue with the survey.

registration_responses.q1: Explaining Citizen Support for Democratic Norm Violation: an online survey experiment in the United States
registration_responses.q2: Gábor Simonovits, Jennifer McCoy, Levente Littvay
registration_responses.q3:

Graham and Svolik (2019) find that only a small group of U.S. voters are willing to punish (vote against) democratic violators, and that those with the strongest policy preferences or partisan loyalty are the least willing to punish democratic violators.  On the other hand, Carey et al (2018) found, more hopefully, that American voters across parties and independents will punish democracy-violating hypothetical candidates on some issues, even after taking into account the stronger effects of partisan identity and policy preferences in determining vote choice. 
While the experimental studies did not, for the most part, find differences among the parties on their willingness to punish democratic violators, survey research does find partisan or ideological differences in support for democracy in the U.S., with Republicans and conservatives more likely to support behavior representing democratic norm violation (Drutman, Diamond, and Goldman, 2018a; Stolle, Gidengil, and Bergeron-Boutin 2019; Wike, et al 2017, 10; Doherty, et al 2017, 3). 
This paper employs a large online survey experiment in the United States to test whether American voters are more tolerant of behavior that violates existing democratic norms when their own party is in power, versus when the opposing party is in power.  Particularly in a context of hyper-polarization such as contemporary U.S. politics, we expect that voters will prioritize keeping their co-partisans in power over protecting existing norms, and that this will be conditioned by intensity of party identity.  Second, we test whether there are differences among Democrats and Republicans in their attitudes toward democratic-norm eroding behavior.
registration_responses.q4:
Our hypotheses are thus:
H1: Citizens are more supportive of democratic norm erosion when co-partisans are in power.

H2: Higher perceptions of out-group threat and the intensity of partisan identity increase support for democratic norm erosion when co-partisans are in power..
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: We use simple randomization through the in-built feature of Qualtrics.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q13: We field the experiment to a sample of 3,000 subjects in the context of a multi-investigator project. Lucid charges $1/subject and sets a maximum survey length. Thus, the size of the study was determined by the resource constraints of the collaborative team.
registration_responses.q21: We will report 95% Confidence intervals corresponding to two-sided tests.
registration_responses.q22:
We give an attention check to terminate respondents indicative of fraudulent responses. In particular,  they responded to a “trick question” proposed by Berinsky et al (2014). Then, we ask them to respond to a simple open ended question about a movie they had watched recently. We do so in order to screen out respondents unwilling or unable to engage with the essay writing stimuli which are our experimental interventions. Finally, because our hypotheses pertain to individuals with some attachment to either the Democrat or Republican party we terminate the survey for individuals who identify as pure independents. 

Thus, our analysis sample will consist of survey takers that 

(1) Identify or lean Democrat or Republican as per our ANES type question
(2) Pass our screener questions.
registration_responses.q23: We force respondents to respond to each of our outcome measures to continue with the survey.
registration_responses.q8.question: The study employs a between-subjects design in which participants are given a scenario about the post-2020 election results and asked a series of questions about democratic norms. In one condition, Democrats control the presidency, governorship of the respondent’s state, and at least one chamber in the Congress.  In the second condition, Republicans control those offices. Thus, for each respondent we manipulate whether the in-party or the out-party is the incumbent.
registration_responses.q12.question: We field our survey through Lucid, the largest US marketplace for online panels. Participants sign up to become members of panels with Providers. These Providers contract with Lucid, who directs participants to purchasers (typically market research firms, but here us, the researchers). Participants are reimbursed by the Providers, typically with money or reward points.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The single manipulated variable in the experiment is whether subjects are prompted to imagine a scenario in which the in-party or the out-party controls government. Specifically, before answering to our outcome measures subjects read one of the preambles below:

Condition 1 - Democrats in power: For the next set of  questions about the government, imagine this  scenario:  It's January 2021, and the new president, Senate and Congress and state level officials are  being inaugurated following the 2020 elections. The Democrats have made a sweep, winning the presidency, the Senate, and the governorship of your state.  In a few of the questions below, though, the Republicans have won a majority in the Congress (House of Representatives).

Condition 2 -- Republicans in power:  For the next set of  questions about the government, imagine this  scenario:  It's January 2021, and the new president, Senate and Congress and state level officials are  being inaugurated following the 2020 elections. The Republicans have made a sweep, winning the presidency, the Senate, and the governorship of your state.  In a few of the questions below, though, the Democrats have retained a majority in the Congress (House of Representatives).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Pre-treatment measures:

Pre-treatment variables

Because we are interested in the relative attitudes of our subjects towards individuals belonging to their in-party and out-party, we first elicit their partisan identification using the ANES questions to identify party supporters and party-leaners for both the Democratic and Republican parties.  We terminate true independents or smaller third parties.

We also measure subjects’ partisan identity strength using a series of 4 questions developed by Huddy, Mason and Aaroe (2015). 


How well does the term Democrat/Republican describe you? (Extremely well - Not well at all)
How important is being a Democrat/Republican to you? (Extremely important - not at all important)
When talking about Democrat/Republican, how often do you use "we" instead of "they"? (Never - All the time)
How much do you have a lot in common with other ${e://Field/respondent_party}s. (Not at all-Great deal)

We combine these responses - all measured on a 5 point scale - to come up with a continuous measure of identity strength. Given that we have found during our pilots that this variable is highly predictive of our outcome of interest we use this variable as a covariate in our statistical analysis.

Finally, we measure perceptions of out-group threat using the items below:

When you look at Democrat/Republican politicians, would you agree that their policies are so misguided they threaten the country's well-being?  [Only the out-party politician/party is displayed]
When you look at President Trump/Bernie Sanders, would you agree that his policies are so misguided they threaten the country's well-being?  [Only the out-party politician/party is displayed]
When you look at people who don't share your values, would you say the policies they advocate are so misguided they threaten the country's well-being?  

We combine responses to these three items to an additive index of threat-perception.


Outcomes

We ask a series of questions about 16 hypothetical situations. In each of these situation we ask subjects to choose between two alternative with one labeled as "norm-eroding" (see wording and response options in the document attached). From these responses we construct a measure of norm erosion using a two parameter IRT model.
registration_responses.q18.question:
For the pre-treatment variables we use simple additive indices scaled to lie between 0 and 100.

For the outcome measures we use a two-parameter IRT model to obtain an estimate of the latent preference for norm erosion.
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: We compare our measure of support for democratic norm erosion across scenarios where co-partisans vs. the out-party is in power. We do so by estimating a simple regression predicting the outcome by an indicator for experimental group.

H2: Higher perceptions of out-group threat and the intensity of partisan identity increase support for democratic norm erosion when co-partisans are in power..

We test this hypothesis by estimating a regression predicting the outcome by an indicator for experimental group interacted with (a) our composite measure of partisan identity strength and (b) or composite measure of threat perception. We estimates these two models separately.

We will also estimate the models above separately for Republican and Democrat respondents.
